componenttext: Okay, great, thank you and congrats on a solid quarter. I was hoping to ask a question about supplies. It did look like supplies were perhaps a little bit below normal seasonal in the quarter. And was just wondering if there was any particular story there? And then I have a follow up.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we saw in supplies, as youll remember for the first two quarters of this year and the last year we saw bit of a pull down in supplies, particularly through 2009, and we started to see a little bit of a bounce-back in the beginning of 2010. So, wha
componenttext: What we saw in supplies, as youll remember for the first two quarters of this year and the last year we saw bit of a pull down in supplies, particularly through 2009, and we started to see a little bit of a bounce-back in the beginning of 2010. So, what were seeing now is a leveling-off of that supplies inventory in the channel. So, I wouldnt actually interpret that or read a lot into it, except to say that, I think that our partners who had a good supply level. So, we have nothing unusual. I just think that they are at a level, where they can actually operate their business effectively.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then for Larry. Larry, could you just give us a little bit more detail on what the additional restructuring actions for the Q4 in 2011 entail, and exactly what you are planning on doing there?
componenttext: And then for Larry. Larry, could you just give us a little bit more detail on what the additional restructuring actions for the Q4 in 2011 entail, and exactly what you are planning on doing there?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Restructuring is focused on actually one of the areas across the business to keep us cost competitive. Its really focused on getting ahead of the curve here. We obviously had a lot of pressure on costs associated with unfavorable exchange rates, partic
componenttext: Restructuring is focused on actually one of the areas across the business to keep us cost competitive. Its really focused on getting ahead of the curve here. We obviously had a lot of pressure on costs associated with unfavorable exchange rates, particularly the yen. We wanted to get restructuring all behind us as we go into 2011, so that we have a sort of a clean playing field going forward. So, its across the board. There is a lot of focus on product cost, supply chain, cost of service in particular, infrastructure generally spread across those areas.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Larry, if I could just follow-up one more time. What exactly can you do in terms of restructuring to help you with the yen problem? It seems like I know you have a currency sharing agreement with Fuji Xerox and I think you go back and renegotiate pricing
componenttext: Larry, if I could just follow-up one more time. What exactly can you do in terms of restructuring to help you with the yen problem? It seems like I know you have a currency sharing agreement with Fuji Xerox and I think you go back and renegotiate pricing with them based on yen moves. But what would fall into the restructuring bucket that would help you there, please?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the first thing is the way we approach currency changes is that its cost. So, you have to get in your mind that its cost, then you have to compare where cost was, where it is, and where it needs to go. It just means that you have to find way
componenttext:
I think the first thing is the way we approach currency changes is that its cost. So, you have to get in your mind that its cost, then you have to compare where cost was, where it is, and where it needs to go. It just means that you have to find ways to get your costs lower. So, some of that happens through changing your sourcing to some degree, which weve try to optimize. Some of it is restructuring around the whole supply chain of how you move product around the world, where you store it, those kinds of things have to be focused on in this restructuring around that.
And then you have to look at other areas, where you cant do any additional in that specific, you have to look at other areas that offset it. So, even though infrastructure has nothing to do with currency in order to make sure that we have a balanced operating margin, which is really the important measurement here, we go after other areas. So I might take infrastructure out of corporate to offset some of exchange rate effects, because you cant get it all in the short term. So I think thats how we look at it.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Richard, if I may, just add on to Larrys point, its important to actually broaden the spectrum when we look at what happens from a currency perspective in 2010. What we suspect, will continue on the go-forward basis. So, Larrys point, I just want
componenttext: Richard, if I may, just add on to Larrys point, its important to actually broaden the spectrum when we look at what happens from a currency perspective in 2010. What we suspect, will continue on the go-forward basis. So, Larrys point, I just want to reiterate it, is not that we actually look at the source of the problem, which in this case is currency, we look at all of the areas and levels that we can pull as a solution to that problem, and its not only where the source is, its everywhere in the corporation. We dont expect it to be a huge positive turn in currency in next year. So, we have to prepare ourselves for today being the reality on a go-forward basis.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I am good. Good especially after this quarter. So could you talk a bit about printing trends? What were just trying to understand is sort of where the pages are coming and clearly color continues to grow, but what youre hearing from your customers i
componenttext: I am good. Good especially after this quarter. So could you talk a bit about printing trends? What were just trying to understand is sort of where the pages are coming and clearly color continues to grow, but what youre hearing from your customers in terms of their willingness to print and any thoughts you have on sort of the impact from tablets and some of the other pressures out there?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Its a good question. What were seeing is a continuation of one set of trends and a little bit of pickup in another. So let me talk about the continuation of trends. Black and white pages at high-end are still declining, and they are declining for a
componenttext:
Its a good question. What were seeing is a continuation of one set of trends and a little bit of pickup in another. So let me talk about the continuation of trends. Black and white pages at high-end are still declining, and they are declining for a couple of reasons. One is driven by Xerox and thats a big push towards color, and we continue to invest in R&D, selling, marketing, everything that we can towards pushing more and more color pages and that clearly is helping customers decide to move to color.
The second is that there are certain technologies; Internet technologies, e-technologies that drive pages away, particularly transactional like bill pages away towards viewing, towards other mechanisms to see them and to operate, own them. Those trends are continuing, and they are moving pages away from black and white particularly at the high-end.
What we see on the flip side is a move more toward color. We showed that with color page growth, color revenue growth, color is a percentage of revenue growing and thats positive and our position in the marketplace in color is stronger than our competitors by far across every industry, across every line of business, every product type, across every industry. So color is increasing as it has been and black and white particular at the high-end is decreasing. Were also seeing a move as we push more in BPO toward operating an infrastructure a little bit less on a paper base and moving it more towards the services base.
So while these things are moving around, we are preparing and prepared to cover a document process, thats paper-based, in any means that the customer wants to be able to operate and own it. So we see small and medium businesses obviously, developing markets doing better than U.S. large businesses, but were also seeing a little trend up in enterprise printing, particularly in color. Net-net, Ill give you a long answer. Net-net, good movement; black and white, down at the high-end, were covering that with color, increasing color up everywhere and we have color offerings everywhere; BPO picking up across the board.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just, sort of, a follow-up on that. In terms of the competitive landscape, can you talk a little bit about what youre seeing from the competitors? I mean, it appears with 54% growth in units for the high-end and on color and substantial growth for othe
componenttext: Just, sort of, a follow-up on that. In terms of the competitive landscape, can you talk a little bit about what youre seeing from the competitors? I mean, it appears with 54% growth in units for the high-end and on color and substantial growth for other color devices that youre gaining share. But could you talk a little bit about where you think the shares are moving and how you think Xerox is going to view the competition?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know Shannon, we see share in a quarter lag, so I can talk about quarter two share and then my thoughts on what we did in quarter three. Quarter two, you saw share increase in just about every segment, particularly in color. Even in black and white
componenttext:
As you know Shannon, we see share in a quarter lag, so I can talk about quarter two share and then my thoughts on what we did in quarter three. Quarter two, you saw share increase in just about every segment, particularly in color. Even in black and white, interestingly our share increased to that point of declining base. So, share increasing on across the board in color. What were seeing from specific competitors, its hard to say it this way, but were seeing nothing too exciting. So, everyone is competing in the marketplace with their specialties.
So, Lexmark focuses on the mid-to-low-end printing area, and they have not expanded out of that, they have not operated in an unusual way at all, and were competing well against them. All the way up to HP that operates a little bit broader-based, theyre not doing anything unusual and were definitely competing well against them. So, at the low end, we continue to launch products, we continue to expand distribution. At the high-end, we continue to launch products and continue to expand distribution. We dont really see a big change at all. I was waiting for little bit more in our competitive reactions.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a couple as well. Could you talk a little about why your gross margins were down somewhat sequentially in sales?
componenttext: I had a couple as well. Could you talk a little about why your gross margins were down somewhat sequentially in sales?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We look at operating margins first as a most important metric, especially as our business moves more with most services mixed in. The margins on services as you know are lower than on equipment, and with mixing more and more to a service to the business.
componenttext:
We look at operating margins first as a most important metric, especially as our business moves more with most services mixed in. The margins on services as you know are lower than on equipment, and with mixing more and more to a service to the business. So, we look at operating margins Im very pleased with the growth in operating margins almost a point quarter-to-quarter basis and more a point on year-over-year basis, so first there.
And then if you look at third quarter, third quarter is traditionally our weakest margin quarter, fourth quarter will bounce back with more revenue on the cost base that we have. So, seasonality and mix of revenues with more services, and clearly, we had to outline a pretty strong headwind from the yen, and we did a pretty good job with that. We covered a lot of it on a year-over-year basis. Its still down slightly, but did a lot of work to cover that headwind. So, I would not interpret the margin on a quarter-to-quarter basis as a big signal. We have to look at that, but also look at operating margins quarter-to-quarter and year-to-year, (inaudible)

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just push a little bit as a way to think about the larger influences there. Was the yen the biggest determinant in either the sales or the service, outsourcing and rentals? Both have been declined 50, 60 basis points. Is there a way to prioriti
componenttext: If I could just push a little bit as a way to think about the larger influences there. Was the yen the biggest determinant in either the sales or the service, outsourcing and rentals? Both have been declined 50, 60 basis points. Is there a way to prioritize what the impact was relative to all those forces that you just mentioned?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that you have two factors that you have to consider. Clearly the yen is the big one, but also seasonality is the big one as well. We have less revenue in this quarter and more costs, and supplies last year or last quarter were stronger, and suppli
componenttext: I think that you have two factors that you have to consider. Clearly the yen is the big one, but also seasonality is the big one as well. We have less revenue in this quarter and more costs, and supplies last year or last quarter were stronger, and supplies have stronger margins as well. So supply is down a little bit, but in line what we expect them to be, and service is mixing up in our business and the yen, clearly a headwind, but we were able to offset a lot of the yen impact in the quarter.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Weve talked about this in the last call and it works a little bit. So we got probably a 60th of the signings in a quarter, starting after you sign it, if you know what I mean. So, a 60th of it. So as we continue to sign more and more and more of annual
componenttext:
Weve talked about this in the last call and it works a little bit. So we got probably a 60th of the signings in a quarter, starting after you sign it, if you know what I mean. So, a 60th of it. So as we continue to sign more and more and more of annual recurring revenue or total contract value revenue, more importantly, youll see (inaudible). So 12 months from now well see a big positive from what we just signed and then it will continue to grow. So I think its starting now, Keith, but you wont see the full set, but it does vary by line of business depending on where we sign.
Most of our signings are on this total contract value basis and across the business lines they kind of come in at the same way. We do have some business that we call walk in and takeover, where when we sign the business, the revenue grows immediately. But this business is not that much like that. We prefer to have total contract value growth. So youll see it coming, its just is not that weve modeled that out, when youll be able to see it all.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think part of the problem too Keith, is that those two businesses are little more affected by the economy and they are a little more affected by the current account usage volume that goes on in those accounts and that along with new account revenue that
componenttext: I think part of the problem too Keith, is that those two businesses are little more affected by the economy and they are a little more affected by the current account usage volume that goes on in those accounts and that along with new account revenue that youre adding, youre getting a minus year from some of the volume thats going on a little bit like usage on multifunction devices. So that is having a moderating effect and as that starts to improve, hopefully, as the economy gets better next year, I think the combination of both of them will show growth in those two areas.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: So three lines of businesses if I can just. One is BPO, the other one is ITO, and the last is document outsourcing. BPO is strong everywhere, signing, pipeline revenue growth, et cetera, very, very good and following a very strong trend grew revenues 8%.
componenttext: So three lines of businesses if I can just. One is BPO, the other one is ITO, and the last is document outsourcing. BPO is strong everywhere, signing, pipeline revenue growth, et cetera, very, very good and following a very strong trend grew revenues 8%. ITO, a little bit more muted and document outsourcing more muted, not on signings that was good, but usage on current accounts that where we are seeing if theres any dampening on that, and particularly in document outsourcing in ITO. The wind is at the back in BPO.

Net-net, well have a positive contribution from Services, and youll see that in our growth rates in 2011. I dont see any

componenttext: Yes, that is what we laid out. It does work out this way. Ben, we can actually spend more time offline. You have total growth and then you have obviously takeaways, grow over accounts, you have lots of different mix issues in the business. But the growth in services we expect to be in 7% to 9% range, which is what we said in the Analyst Day. BPO grow in the highest, ITO grow in the lowest.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, off to a good start with that visibility. And then I just want to clarify the other thing. Larry said is that, when you see the signings like this, some of this is consolidation of fleets, document outsourcing especially. That would lower usage
componenttext: Obviously, off to a good start with that visibility. And then I just want to clarify the other thing. Larry said is that, when you see the signings like this, some of this is consolidation of fleets, document outsourcing especially. That would lower usage also as part of the plan. Does that have a cannibalizing effect too? So, extrapolate this too positively. Could you just go a little more detail about, you mentioned it with Keith a little bit, but I think there is an offset there in terms of usage that you guys are driving, and as well as the economy and I was wondering if you could delineate between those two which is an offset as well?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is too different hydraulics that happened here. Ben, first is that when we engage a document outsourcing customer the vast majority of time that we do that, we are consolidating printer fleet that is not Xerox fleet. Because were not the biggest
componenttext:
There is too different hydraulics that happened here. Ben, first is that when we engage a document outsourcing customer the vast majority of time that we do that, we are consolidating printer fleet that is not Xerox fleet. Because were not the biggest player in printers. Its Lexmark, HP as you know. Single function, particularly monochrome printers; thats an add to us. As we run those accounts, first year, second year, third year, as you run those accounts, volumes need to go up or down depending on how the economy is working, how the industry is going.
What Larry is referring to is not the upfront engagement which is growing for us. There is no doubt about it. You see that in our document outsourcing signings. What were talking about is once youre in the account, volumes go up, and volumes go down. Sometimes they go up, because the business is growing or because weve introduced another service. They can also go down, because the business that we done the takeover and is not growing or were losing a service. Thats what he is talking about, not the initial signings. He is talking the volume in the account once weve signed it.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, I think I know the answer, but with all the cash flow that you see coming in the fourth quarter where you normally have a very strong performance. How is that going on your pace to returning cash for shareholders by mid next year, a
componenttext: And then just finally, I think I know the answer, but with all the cash flow that you see coming in the fourth quarter where you normally have a very strong performance. How is that going on your pace to returning cash for shareholders by mid next year, and what is your priority if share repurchase versus dividend? Does anything change?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ben, I think we were on a very aggressive pay down of debt. Were actually ahead of that aggressive plan, albeit at a $100 million, so thats very good. Weve given ourselves the flexibility to pay down more debt, so that will help us. Were confi
componenttext: Ben, I think we were on a very aggressive pay down of debt. Were actually ahead of that aggressive plan, albeit at a $100 million, so thats very good. Weve given ourselves the flexibility to pay down more debt, so that will help us. Were confident of the cash flow that fourth quarter is our biggest. If you look back in history here, we close the doors often in the fourth quarter, and thats what were working on to make sure that happens here. Were confident that what we said for the last year is that we will look at share repurchase by mid-2011, and start to return to shareholders. We also look at the dividend as well in the mid-2011 timeframe. So all of that were confident of and as we get closer obviously, there is more confidence.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, thanks guys for taking the question. Ursula, I guess just a quick question about sort of your thinking relative to your expectations as you move to the summer, regarding the underlying installment trends. I mean it feels like this is the first quarte
componenttext:
Hey, thanks guys for taking the question. Ursula, I guess just a quick question about sort of your thinking relative to your expectations as you move to the summer, regarding the underlying installment trends. I mean it feels like this is the first quarter so its a real solid quarter. I think everybody is probably pretty pleased and maybe a little bit surprised kind of across the board. First quarter in any way, where we can kind of say well, like every segment you guys reported on to either sustained positive trends or even subsequently improved. So just want to get your thoughts on how much better are things on, install base is actually going and then maybe you guys start going to the summer and then to the extent they are a little better, what could that mean to Xerox as sort of being with printing more of a late cycle probably when we think about what the tailwind to any sort of revenue might be into 11?
If I could just tie that in with you guys may be updating your 2011 guidance today, you guys typically dont, your pretty prudent management team doesnt do anything unless you feel pretty good about stuff, and so I could read through potentially that that makes you feel on the margin a little bit better about sort of trends heading into next year?
And then just Larry, if you could tie in typically like in 3Q typically working capital is actually a use of source of cash, I mean even as you ramp up for December Q seasonality if we kind of just look back and there was a pretty significant use of cash, presumably because you guys are sort of ramping up for some of what youre seeing on install basis. So, I guess the point is, are we looking at a little bit better growth here than we thought that just hasnt really manifested itself in revenue yet heading into 2011?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Very long question. I think Ill catch it all and then if I dont, you can point out where Ive missed. On the question of how were feeling, how is the economy going. I think we saw an uptick, even though slight, in small mid-sized businesses and
componenttext:
Very long question. I think Ill catch it all and then if I dont, you can point out where Ive missed. On the question of how were feeling, how is the economy going. I think we saw an uptick, even though slight, in small mid-sized businesses and in our development markets territory, and thats continuing. So, we havent seen a change in trend there, which is good news. We did see a little uptick in large enterprises this quarter, thats positive. For us, it helps us in activity, if you look at our activity in every segment from the largest thing that we sell; continuous feed machine to the smallest thing that we sell grew including black and white.
So, I think that it would be hard for me to say that things arent looking a little bit better. I am not confident enough yet to say that things this better will stay forever and were not counting on this better staying forever. We have a great product line, we have expanded distribution, but Im still cautious on the economy, particularly in the large enterprises portion of the economy, employment rates havent grown, etc., etc., So, we are approaching the business this quarter and quarters going forward like we have all quarters in the past, which as we approach it cautiously but optimistically.
So, I do believe that weve seen some uptick and until I see the uptick change, Im not going to predict its changing even more. I hope you got help. We do have tailwinds, as I said, but I dont know if theyll continue. 2011 change got to be a mass problem pretty simply. Were now on Q3 and Q3 when you added up and you add up Q4, were going to be past what weve said that what we would do in 2011. So, it was kind of hard to continue to have a conversation about a set of numbers that we were actually running up against in quarter three.
So, there was no magic around updating the guidance for 2011. We could have waited, I guess. There is no magic, there is no exciting thing about it, except for that when you look at it were going to be at $0.92 to $0.93 this year full year, this year, its kind of hard to stay at $0.95 next year. So, we decided to do it because of the math looked out the way that it worked out.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we do feel optimistic about next year as well. Well (inaudible) at the end of the fourth quarter in January, and well report while certainly revisit it. But I think given where we are in the year and quarters behind us were confident goin
componenttext:
I think we do feel optimistic about next year as well. Well (inaudible) at the end of the fourth quarter in January, and well report while certainly revisit it. But I think given where we are in the year and quarters behind us were confident going forward here.
On the cash side, I think you have to look back at 2009 here. We had an enormous constraint on anything associated with cash. We obviously didnt have volume on supplies or machines in 2009, and so we pulled back significantly on inventory. By the way, there were some flyers that went away, I mean there is a lot of stuff that is not announced or talked about.
So, the whole three quarters of 2010 has really been building back demand and also the inventory levels to support that demand. So, thats what weve done for three quarters. Were confident that in the fourth quarter, were going to have very good demand, were going to have good revenue growth, and were going to ship that supply in the inventory now, and its going to be a source of cash.
We also have a quarter where we concentrate these (inaudible) so we concentrate more on accounts receivable and getting things collected by the end of the year then maybe we should do in earlier parts of the year. So, Im confident that will be better, and then were going to have a good profit quarter. So, all of those lead to confidence in the cash flow.

componenttextpreview: So, I think that youll see across the board, we saw growth quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So, new business signings were for this quarter up 17%, last quarter they were up 16%. So, new business is good. Renewals are very good. We had a high ren
componenttext:
So, I think that youll see across the board, we saw growth quarter-to-quarter and year-over-year. So, new business signings were for this quarter up 17%, last quarter they were up 16%. So, new business is good. Renewals are very good. We had a high renewal quarter; last quarter, we have another good one. We give a range of 85% to 90%, and were trending at the high end of that range we did last quarter and were seeing that this quarter as well.
So all aspects, so signings, pipeline signings and how that signings come from synergy, from renewals are all trending very well. We did sign a couple of deals in Europe as well, so this is a kind of working out the way that we had laid out for it to workout.

componenttext: Actually, but I mean obviously not 30 out of 30. I mean some dont go to contact at all, some well before we go down to stage two, move to someone else. This is really, really hard to actually start to quantify the close rate. I think once we get into this a little bit more we can actually figure it out, yes. So 30 clients so far, 30 customers, 30 signings, international as well as U.S., strong synergy mix, baseline business is going well as well, baseline business in BPO, baseline in ITO, and baseline in document outsourcing. So, I think a pretty good mix.

componenttext:
So, yes, we saw install growth across all lines of business, and we saw misgrowth as well, which is more of the indicator than even the install growth, and it depends on the size of machine and the type of account. Since were dealing with a very large pro-sale number, which is a very, very large pro-sale number. You start to see the growth slower. Youll not see percentage points grow quickly, so next month you wont see the impact of this 20% increase in activity. But you will see, and what youve already seen is the flattening out of the pro-sale to starting to grow through quarters.
So, it will start today, Doug, its just that if the numbers are small on a very, very large base. The way that I think about this is there is nothing bad about putting in a machine, theres not a thing bad about putting on in. The more you put in, the better it goes. The bigger they are, the better it goes. What you can look here is that we have growth in high-end color. We had growth in black and white. We had growth in mid-range, et cetera. So, (inaudible) are in this revenue growth and then they are comprehended into the outlook that we gave for the quarter and for 2011.

componenttext:
Remember Doug, youre talking about four-year contracts here. So, if you look at the service content of it, youre adding about 148 of the service content every month, and so you multiply that by the growth rate, I think you would see, what I would say here too is that you would see growth immediately if we werent facing the same problem we talked about before, which is that, if there is a lower usage level that you see with customers on the bulk of the myth that Ursula has talked about.
So, its very hard to see but this is the kind of thing that slowly adds to the growth rate. If you look at past history, we were down and flat and within the two year period we got to 3%. So, I think you will see the positive signs of this coming through as a get into 2011.

componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. Good morning. Two quick questions, if I could. Ursula, can you talk a little more about the ECS deal synergies in terms of the deal size? It seems like the incremental in terms of 30 deals new at least versus 10 previously in terms of sign
componenttext:
Yes, thank you. Good morning. Two quick questions, if I could. Ursula, can you talk a little more about the ECS deal synergies in terms of the deal size? It seems like the incremental in terms of 30 deals new at least versus 10 previously in terms of signings going from 2.5 to 3.5. It seems like that deal sizes are getting smaller. Should we contemplate that as kind of been term line going forward?
And then Larry, if you could weigh in briefly here, I know you answered Richards question earlier about the additional cost cutting. Im just trying to get a sense of, what is the driver there of the impetus just given that youre still early here on the ACS piece. Your business tones seem pretty constructive here. So, why there is restructuring now?

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first part on deal sizing, and Larry can go on to second part of the question. Our deals are $5 million to $10 million, average deal size and we havent seen a fundamental change there in that deal size. Were seeing which is good, which is what w
componenttext: The first part on deal sizing, and Larry can go on to second part of the question. Our deals are $5 million to $10 million, average deal size and we havent seen a fundamental change there in that deal size. Were seeing which is good, which is what we want to see happen, deals that we see in account or places that we are new, we start small and we grow over time, but the annual current revenue is about $5 million to $10 million. As I said, the seeding is good, so nothing, no indicators of anything changing in that mode, even though its early days.

headline: Xerox Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the first point here is that we want to go into 2011 as cost competitive as we can. We dont want to do restructuring going forward. We want to have that a little behind us in order to get our synergies airborne early as fast as we can, and in o
componenttext: I think the first point here is that we want to go into 2011 as cost competitive as we can. We dont want to do restructuring going forward. We want to have that a little behind us in order to get our synergies airborne early as fast as we can, and in order to make sure that were cost competitive because of the exchange rate changes. We wanted to get that all behind us, and thats really whats the motivation between the restructuring. Its pretty straight forward. There is nothing additional to that and it just seemed to make sense to move it ahead.
